title: meghan markle prince harry royal tradition karren brady
story: Also, congratulations are due for breaking with royal tradition and doing things their way, and not submitting to being photographed outside the Lindo Wing within hours of giving birth.Some sayyou marry into the Royal Family, a public le goes with the territory. But we must try to find a balance.The royals have long-established traditions and do not like change.But given how intense le is for new parents, who can blame Meghan and Harry for wanting to enjoy it alone for a bit Most women avoid cameras for weeks after giving birth. So having a photo taken, under pressure to look gorgeous, scrutinised from every angle, just a couple of days after giving birth  That is a huge ask.I didn’t get out of my pyjamas for a week both times after I had children.Harry and Meghan did a fantastic job introducing Archie to the world.I loved how Harry carried his baby in, already the hands-on father he wants to be, alight with the joy of new fatherhood.However, it was impossible not to think about how wonderful Diana would have been as a grandmother.The birth of a son must be bittersweet for Harry, knowing Diana will never meet Archie.While some grumbled about the two-day wait to show off the baby, others recommend a “babymoon” for parents to shut out the rest of the world and bond with their baby for a week or two.Something tells me that would have been Meghan and Harry’s preference, so this was a compromise.They understand they are public figures.Archie is seventh in line to the throne and his parents know that taxpayers, who in part pay their salary, expected to meet the baby at some point.Most of us only wish to send our love, wish the new parents well and share the moment with them.Within hours of the birth, Meghan’s half-sister had suggested the new arrival meant Meghan was morally obliged to reconnect with her father, Thomas Markle.Let’s be clear. Meghan doesn’t have to do any such thing.She is better off without a father she can’t trust.If your own family are not up to scratch, you make your own based on love, trust and happiness.Given how happy Meghan and Harry look with Archie, they are doing just fine with that.A couple of things really stood out for me about the way they introduced their baby to the world.First, didn’t Meghan look amazing in her Grace Wales Bonner-designed dress I love the fact she chose white, which clearly showed her post-baby bump.She knows what a role model is.And she knows better than to create unrealistic aspirations for women who have just given birth.After all, most mothers still have the bump for at least a few weeks after having a baby.Then there was the look of sheer happiness on the Queen’s face as she looked down at her new great-grandson.Even with her many children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren, she radiated a delight she shares with grandmothers up and down the land.It was just beautul to behold.MAMMA mia! Looking at the cover of Sports Illustrated’s annual swimsuit issue – featuring model and entrepreneur Tyra Banks – it’s impossible to believe Tyra’s first cover was  years ago and she came out of “modelling retirement” for the shoot.The very idea of wearing a yellow string bikini – at any age, let alone  – is unimaginable to most of us mere mortals.Butyou’ve got it, flaunt it . . . and Tyra certainly still has it.I AM increasingly convinced the only way to grow old gracefully is simply to accept that it’s happening.So I feel bad for Katie Price, who at  had another facelt last month in Turkey.On Wednesday’s Good Morning Britain, the ex-model discussed her “addiction” to plastic surgery.She explained how she had her own fat injected under her eyes and had the side of her face “lted” in a bid to look more youthful.It sounds horric. Choosing to have serious surgery to look a bit younger is baffling.Maybe she feels defined by her looks and will do anything to hang on to them.When I look at pictures of Katie or watch her on TV, I wish she would be kinder to herself and love herself more.She should worry more about how she feels than how she looks.She needs a best friend – someone who knows everything about her and still loves her – to tell her to stop scratching the wrong itch.Katie should give up the plastic surgery and learn to love herself the way she are . . . wrinkles and all.NOT sure I’ll be taking up Lisa Snowdon’s tip for keeping an eye on how much she eats – using chopsticks for every meal instead of a kne and fork.The TV presenter, , says they slow down her eating, so she feels full more quickly.But whatyou are having soup I HAD a chuckle about the fact that Gregg Wallace’s favoured comment on his we Anne-Marie’s Instagram account is the suggestion that she print out a photo.Someone has compiled a mega-tweet of the many times he has commented on his -year-old partner’s photos, demanding she “print it”.When it comes to social media, that sort of defeats the object.Gregg, I feel for you. It’s hard getting older – and it sucks not understanding the modern way of doing things.WHEN Donald Trump refused to publish his tax s, I assumed it was because he didn’t want people to know how much money he had.It turns out it was because he had so little.His tax s reveal he “lost more money than almost any other American taxpayer for a decade, after his hotels and casinos racked up .BILLION dollars in losses”.So not quite the billionaire he claims he is . . .  or the ace businessman.PERHAPS the most surprising news of this week is that although more alcohol is now being drunk around the world, we Brits are not responsible for the rise.We call them snowflakes but, very often, the young people I meet are much more focused and impressive than my generation ever was.APPARENTLY it’s not just booze we Brits are giving up. Thanks to technology, we are now having less SEX than ever before, too.A major study found there has been a steep decline in rates of intimacy since , with fewer than half of Britons now having sex once a week.Scientists said that “le in the digital age” was partly to blame – with couples now too distracted by Netflix, social media or their phones to focus on each other.But seriously,you prefer Netflix or your phone to sex with your partner... well, it’s time for a orce, I’d say.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: michael schumacher ski accident documentary cannes
story: In , the Formula  legend was skiing in the French alps when he crashed into a rock and suffered a traumatic brain injury that left him paralysed and unable to speak.Since the near-fatal accident, details of his health have been under wraps by his family and friends - but he has reportedly been living at his home in Gland, Switzerland, dependant on a team of doctors and carers.Now, almost six years after the tragic crash that ended his career, the driving legends story will be told in a new documentary called Schumacher.A trailer for the feature- documentary will debut at Cannes Film Festival this week.The film will feature interviews with Schumachers family and never-before-seen footage of the legend at home with his family, before and after the accident.The Times reports that Schumachers -year-old father Rolf will be interviewed by award-winning filmmakers Michael Wech and Hanns-Bruno Kammertons.The film will also feature interviews from his we Corinna and the couples two children Gina, , and Mick, .His family worked closely with the filmmakers to create the documentary.It will also show scenes from Shumachers th birthday celebrations, which took place this year at the familys villa in Mallorca where he was flown by private helicopter.The film is due to be released in German and Swiss cinemas on December , but the foreign license rights will be up for grabs at the film festival this week.This means big streaming services like Amazon and Netflix will potentially bid for the rights to stream the film in the UK.The family’s publicist, Sabine Kehm, said the film marked a quarter of a century since Schumacher’s legendary world championship victory over British rival, Damon Hill.Kehm said: “Michael’s outstanding career deserves to be celebrated  years after the first of his seven world titles.Schumacher was skiing off-piste with his then -year-old son and a group of friends in the French resort of Meribel when he crashed in the near-fatal accident.Doctors said the accident would have killed Schumacher had he not been wearing a helmet.He was placed in an induced coma for three months, but his health has been kept largely under wraps since.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: deborah james new nsh tool dying less traumatic
story: MyCMC lets patients take control of what happens in an emergency, such as whether they would want to be resuscitated orthey wish to die at home.The NHS scheme, an abbreviation of My Co-ordinate My Care, enables details to be shared between care providers such as , out-of-hours GPs and paramedics.Other details can include emergency contacts, a patients cultural or spiritual beliefs, whether they wish to donate their organs and whether they have a pet that needs to be cared for.Stage four bowel cancer patient and Things Cancer Made Me Say columnist Deborah James has thrown her support behind the tool for the chronically ill and those nearing death.She said: Facing up to an incurable illness is dficult to accept.But we need to engage with death, and part of that means making decisions about how you might want to die at home, or in a hospice.With myCMC, people such as myself can plan for what might happen in the future.It means being in control. It means that, with discussions with my consultant, I can make decisions that help me and my family, and I can get on with living.The Health Secretary Matt Hancock has also backed the move, saying: Im a huge believer in improving the way we provide care for people through the smart use of technology.The best innovations are often brilliantly simple and Co-ordinate My Care is an example which shows the dference the NHS can make to peoples lives when they need it most.I want to see improvements across health and care, and more technology like this can help tailor healthcare to iniduals and help us fulfil the ambition of the NHS Long Term Plan to move to more person-first care.Patients can start their own CMC plan online, in their own time and in their own home.Once they have finished, they can book an appointment with their GP or nurse, who can add clinical details and upload the plan so that it can be shared with health professionals.Research on almost , CMC plans from London - the plan on which the new service is based - found that fewer than one in five people with a plan died in hospital.Around half of all deaths tend to occur in hospital.Professor Julia Riley, the clinical lead for CMC and palliative care consultant at the Royal Marsden, said: CMC came about after I saw the way in which my sister-in-law was cared for when she died.She wanted to die at home, but out-of-hours providers insisted she went to hospital.It would have been betterurgent care providers had known about her wishes in advance.That is why we developed CMC, which has helped thousands share their treatment wishes.

title: moment black humanoid figure descends from sky sending supernatural fans into a frenzy
story: The video was shot in Burbank, Calornia and shows the object gently floating past the tree tops and then down to earth.In the video, the lit up front of a house comes into view as a mans voice can be heard.Setting his stall out early, he says “is that Jesus Christ ” before saying in Spanish “it’s a man”.“It went behind the tree and I can’t see it no more” he says as it disappears behind another tree for a second.At that stage, a clue as to what the strange “humanoid” figure might actually be emerges when the person says: “You don’t think that’s balloons do you ”.The video appears to have been uploaded to YouTube by someone called Pablo Morales, who insisted he “found no balloons or trash or anything that could have been that big”.One person who shared the video said he believed the figure was a Fallen Angel – presumably referring to the biblical idea of angels who have been expelled from heaven.“I believe that this could be a Fallen Angel as how creepy it looked especially when it went out of view,” said the YouTube user.But comments left under the video by other users were more cynical.“Thats balloons” read one while another said “its balloons you - can see it when he zooms on it when it goes down”.

title: child support claiming unemployed ex
story: Rebecca Desmond, , says she filmed Rob Atkinson strutting around the Armthorpe branch of Tesco in Doncaster at around pm after buying alcohol at a self check-out in a hi-vis jacket.When the man, who is wearing a hi-vis yellow jacket and trousers, realises he’s being filmed he mutters weirdo before walking out of the store to a branded Direct Traffic van.Rebecca, a self-employed therapist, said she followed Rob into the store on March  after becoming enraged because she claims he owes her thousands in unpaid child support over the last three and a half years.An unveried benefits letter indicates that Robert Atkinson owes £,. in arrears.The mum-of-one said: “The man owes me thousands in unpaid maintenance but he’s covered head to toe in tattoos.“He’s told everyone he doesn’t work.She added that Rob appeared shocked by the encounter.“Rob didn’t know what to do, she said. He called me a weirdo then he huffed a little bit, had a ‘big man walk’ back to the van and that was it.“He couldnt get out of there quick enough.Rebecca said she welcomed Robs recent attempt to become part of -year-old daughter Freyas le after years of minimal contact.The couple split up ten years ago after four years of dating, when Freya was just nine months old.In September last year Rob got back in touch, sending her card in which he vowed to stop being a rubbish dad.And after visiting his house, Freya was excited to learn she was going to be a bridesmaid at Rob’s wedding in Mexico.Rebecca said: “I thought it was brilliant and welcomed it with open arms only to be met with ‘we’re getting married, we want her to be a bridesmaid but I’m still not going to pay you any money’.“I said that he needed to put some money down and start paying off his debts before playing happy families and then he could take her on holiday.She says that since then Rob has gone off Freyas radar, adding: “I’ve had to work really hard for  years to make sure Freya’s got what she has now.“Now he’s disappeared again and she’s not heard from him since. It’s really cruel, I can’t ever forgive him for that.”Rob, , denies he claimed to be unemployed, and described the allegations against him as absolutely crackers.He says there are outstanding payments because he only recently got a tax code but admits now he needs to ring Child Maintenance Service.And he says claims the letter stating that he owes more than £, in child support arrears is inaccurate as he has only worked here and there over the last couple of years.Rob said he had four children from three mothers.Every single one of the other mothers are all up to date with all their payments, everything’s up to date, everythings sorted, he said. [Rebecca] is the trouble.He claimed he was self-employed and only worked a couple of days work a week.Rob says he was in the army three and a half years ago, and didnt work at all for the first  months as he was medically unwell.He claims the £, figures appeared to have come from totting up £ a month over three years.But he says that the CMS had an incorrect picture of when hed actually worked, and that his income is based on his Army pension.Rob also denied he was getting married, allegedly saying: There’s not a wedding happening, [so there was] no mention of [Freya] being a bridesmaid.A DWP spokesman said they could not comment on inidual cases.The spokesman said: “We’re committed to recovering owed child maintenance and recently introduced tougher powers to take people’s assets into account – including property, savings and investments and self-declared income.If someone suspects their ex-partner of avoiding paying child maintenance, they should inform us straight away so we can investigate fully.”Direct Traffic Management Ltd said they could not comment due to data protection legislation.

title: honda factory swindon close
story: The Japanese car giant will pull down the shutters on its plant in Swindon in .Unions accused the firm of bowing to pressure from Donald Trump to make more cars in the US rather than Europe.The plant currently employs , workers who will be left redundant when it closes in two years.Honda said it was planning to switch its resources to make electric cars instead of petrol-powered vehicles.The company said in a statement: The decision to close the plant is part of Hondas broader global strategy in response to changes to the automotive industry.As previously communicated in February, Honda is accelerating its electrication plans, and as a result resources, capabilities and production systems for electried vehicles will be focused in regions with a high volume of customer demand.The factory currently makes , cars a year.Remainers have previously blamed Brexit for the demise of the plant.But Honda bosses insist there is no link and industry experts say the company has struggled with its overall business strategy.Trade union Unite today blasted the firm and suggested it was motivated by a desire to dodge tarfs which President Trump has slapped on cars imported to the US.National officer Des Quinn said: This body blow is nothing short of a betrayal of the workforce, customers and the wider supply chain which relies on Honda Swindon for work.Labours Rebecca Long-Bailey added: This is devastating news for the workers who have fought tooth and nail to save their jobs.Business Secretary Greg Clark vowed to support those affected and boost other businesses in Swindon to support the areas economy.

title: private island mansion yacht florida usa
story: The beautul vista is located just a few minutes from the nearest airport in Marathon, Florida, and is on sale for a whopping £million.Incredible images show the palm-tree filled, .-acre island from above with a marina and the nearby town of Marathon in the background.Other striking shots show the light-filled interior of the main residence with a modern kitchen, spacious living areas and cosy bedrooms.Pictures also show the exterior of the large building, the extensive porch with spectacular views and a shimmering pool.Palm Island is located in Florida, USA and is currently listed by Private Islands Online for just under £.million.The listing reads: “Situated in the heart of the Florida Keys, nested behind gates and lush tropical landscape is this grand bay-front island with a magnicent main house and two private guest houses, swimming pool, and deep water protected dockage for multiple boats.“The main two-storey home offers two inviting bedrooms, spacious living and dining area, showcase kitchen and French doors that open to lovely porches overlooking the bay.“The impressive guest quarters provide comfort and privacy with four bedrooms, four baths and private patio overlooking the bay.“Lastly the timeless bay-front one-bedroom guest cottage offers open bay views and sandy beach area.”The swimming pool with sundeck is surrounded by swaying Palm trees and tropical gardens.Palm Island is only a few minutes away from the airport.

title: shocking images show conditions kids as young as four worked in to earn under 40p a day in the us
story: Le for some youngsters in the United States in the early th Century was painfully grim with gruelling hours, backbreaking work and no playtime.These remarkable photos were captured by Lewis Hine between  and .He was working as an investigator for the United States’ National Child Labor Committee.The organisation was designed to promote the rights, awareness, dignity, well-being and education of children and youth in relation to their work.His photos show pre-teens smoking whilst rolling cigars in a factory and black-faced children working in dark and dangerous mines as coal “breakers”.They could spend hours in the gloomy, dust-filled darkness patiently waiting to open trapdoors for mining carts to pass through.The pictures also show a four-year-old name Mary shucking oysters alongside her mother who is struggling to juggle her work and her new-born child.Children were forced to work in factories, on farms, or mills which left little or no time for schooling or recreational activities.Teachers would give lessons to empty desks as absent students toiled away to pick that season’s beet.Hine’s photos and campaigning helped raise awareness of the plight many children of the age faced.Although child labour in the UK was prevalent in the Victorian age the problem was arguably worse across the Atlantic.After many repeated and failed attempts to pass a Fair Labor Standards Act, it wasn’t until  that the legislation was passed by Congress.The act fixed minimum ages of  for work during school hours,  for certain jobs after school, and  for dangerous work.Today all the states and the U.S. federal government have laws regulating child labour.

title: more sauce in pot noodles keep aaron ramsey at arsenal and wall off birmingham the bonkers petitions which voters keep sending to no10
story: No has been inundated with bizarre petitions from voters calling for totally impossible outcomes.The outlandish suggestions made by the public include walling off Birmingham from the South, and abolishing Parliament to put the Queen in charge.The policies are among the thousands of petitions sent to Downing Street which have been rejected because the Government could never actually deliver on them.One demands that large Pot Noodles should come with additional sauce - the Brit who set it up said: Sick and tired of king-size Pot Noodles coming with regular sauce sachets  Sign my petition to make change!Another food-related petition calls for Creme Egg McFlurrys toto the McDonalds menu.An Arsenal supporter wrote to Theresa May last month asking her to step in and block Aaron Ramseys transfer to Juventus.He stormed: Arsenal fans are in disarray. As nothing official has been stated signed we need the Government to intervene.A dferent footie fan called on Newport County to be kicked out of the Football League because theyre based in Wales.And a music fanatic said BBC  Music should be forced to play My Sharona by The Knack on the grounds it is unarguably the best song ever.A civil servant responded saying: You might like to write to the BBC to make this suggestion.Another of the rejected petitions demanded the Facebook logo be changed back to what it used to be.And one said there should be a wall outside Birmingham to stop the South of England meddling with the rest of the UK.A petition submitted three weeks ago said: Abolish Parliament and establish an absolute monarchy.But the Government replied: We cant accept your petition because we arent sure what powers you would like to be transferred to the monarch.Any British citizen has the write to petition Mrs May, but impossible demands are automatically rejected by officials.

title: girl mcdonalds hot water disneyland usa
story: Lainey Dombeer, , was passing through Portland International Airport in Oregon while on her way to Disneyland when her tongue was badly burned.Laineys mum Emily told KATU: I turn for a split second to set my wallet down and she just starts screaming bloody murder. was hotter than I would have drank coffee or tea or anything. It was absolutely burning.The worried mum instantly took to Facebook to share shocking images of Laineys burns.She said the ordeal left the family shaken up before their planned holiday.In her post, she wrote: These are special moments, this is her first time to Disneyland.All the pictures that we’re taking, all the princess makeovers that she’ll forever look at, she’ll have a Band-Aid over her chin.So this is something she’ll always remember, unfortunately.Lainey now has blisters on her lip and inside her mouth.She is wearing a bandage on her chin where there is a scar.Despite the alarming incident, the family went on to enjoy their long-awaited trip.However later on, mum Emily was left in anger when McDonalds workers allegedly disregarded her concerns.She said: Extremely unhappy right now with the lack of empathy and compassion of these employees.Something needs to be done because this negligence can just keep happening.I don’t knowthey need better training. Something needs to be done.The owner and operator of the airport McDonald’s, Mike Kennedy, told Sun Online: “The safety of our guests and crew are our top priority.We are taking this claim very seriously and investigating this matter.”

title: california monterey bay whale pictures angler boat
story: The humpback narrowly missed his boat as it crashed back into the water at Monterey Bay, Calornia.Taken by photographer Douglas Croft, , and whale watcher Kate Cummings, the photo shows the whale shooting up through the waves close to a boat with an unsuspecting fisherman in.Douglas said: It was quite exciting! Salmon season coincides with the time when humpbacks are ing to Monterey Bay to feed for the summer and there were hundreds of boats on the bay fishing.This whale had breached a couple of times before this and many times they’ll just keep doing it.I went below deck to shoot from a porthole close to the water line. That’s what gives this amazing perspective of looking up at the whale.That the breach was directly behind the fishing boat really shows the size.Since the boat is closer, it should look bigger, but the whale is huge! If I’d been the fisherman, I’d probably need some new underwear.Kate, who took the video said: It was fun capturing this video. The whale had already breached multiple times much further away from the fisherman.But sometimes when whales breach multiple times, theyre also heading a specic direction when theyre underwater building momentum for the next breach.I figured the next breach would be around the fisherman because the whale was heading that way and sure enough! Though I didnt expect the whale and the boat to line up so perfectly.Here’s our advice for the startled sailor: You’re gonna need a bigger boat.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: chickens kicked on farms supplying nandos asda and lidl
story: Some of the birds collapsed under the weight of their unnaturally large bodies and were left unable to stand.Others were kicked, stamped on and had their necks snapped by workers on three farms in Northamptonshire.The farms are certied by Red Tractor, which claims that “animal health and welfare is at the heart” of its standards.However, dead birds were left to rot around other chickens that started eating them as they lay on the ground.In footage released by charity Animal Equality, some of the animals could be seen struggling aged just seven days old.Disturbing images show workers ruthlessly snapping their necks and leaving them to die.The charity said their accelerated growth causes joint and heart problems as their under-developed bodies try and keep up.The footage was filmed at Evenley, Pimlico and Helmdon farms which all rear chickens for Aa Foods.The firm is a joint venture between Cargill and Faccenda Foods and is one of the UK’s largest chicken companies, which supplies major outlets including Nando’s, Lidl and Asda.The charity’s investigators made multiple visits to the farms between January and March  after receiving a tip-off about poor conditions.After discovering bin bags full of dead birds inside one shed at Evenley Farm, they installed a hidden camera to record how long the carcasses were left among the living.Animal Equality’s UK Director, Dr Toni Vernelli, said: “Sensationalist headlines about American chlorinated chicken would have us believe that British birds live a le of luxury, but these harrowing scenes reveal the truth.“Crammed inside crowded sheds and bred to grow so unnaturally large that their joints and hearts can’t cope with the strain, chickens on British farms suffer every minute of their lives.“Labels and certicates don’t prevent animals from suffering in the meat industry, but consumers can.“Delicious, plant-based options are now widely available in shops and restaurants across the UK. It’s never been easier to leave chickens off your plate.”All of the footage has been passed to the RSPCA, Red Tractor and Defra’s Animal and Plant Health Agency.A Nando’s spokesman told the Mirror: “Animal welfare is as important to us as it is to customers, which is why all of our chickens are barn-reared in the UK to Red Tractor standards.“We expect all our suppliers to operate to high standards and we are disappointed with the footage.“We will be working with the supplier to get to the bottom of these allegations.”An Aa Foods spokesman told The Sun Online: “We take our responsibilities for the birds in our care very seriously and their health and welfare is of the utmost importance.“Our farmers are required to carefully inspect flocks on a daily basis – to identy any birds requiring attention or which may need to be culled.“We have closely examined the contents of this report to assess compliance against our procedures.“Initial findings indicate that, for the farm involved, our requirement to remove any culled or fallen birds as soon as they are identied has not been followed.“We will take all necessary action to ensure that this situation does not reoccur.“Anyone found not to be meeting our standards will be subjected to comprehensive retraining and further steps will be takenappropriate.“Red Tractor, the RSPCA and the Government’s Animal  Plant Health Agency have also made unannounced visits since this footage was taken and were satisfied with the health and welfare of the birds.”A spokesman for restaurant chain Nando’s said: “Animal welfare is as important to us as it is to customers, which is why all of our chickens are barn-reared in the UK to Red Tractor standards.“We expect all our suppliers to operate to high standards and we are disappointed with the footage.“We will be working with the supplier to get to the bottom of these allegations.”Asda and Lidl referred to a statement from the British Retail Consortium.The BRC said: “Our members take their responsibilities to animal welfare very seriously and work closely with trusted suppliers so that high welfare standards are upheld.“They have strict processes in place and will thoroughly investigate any evidence of non-conformity to ensure that any problems are immediately addressed.”Pimlico Farm referred to the statement from Aa Foods while Helmdon and Evenley were unavailable for comment.

title: jeremy hunt increase britain defence budget
story: The Foreign Secretary called for “a strengthening of our hard power” in the next defence review to cement Britain’s place in a post-Brexit world.The powerful intervention is the boldest yet in a shadow Tory leadership contest already being fought by more than a dozen senior MPs.The offer from Mr Hunt – seen as one of the frontrunners to succeed Theresa May – will be seen as tailor-made to appeal to Tory members.He told the Lord Mayor’s Banquet last night: ““I believe it is time for the next Strategic Defence and Security Review to ask whether, over the coming decade, we should decisively increase the proportion of GDP we devote to defence.“The outcome of such investment should demonstrate beyond doubt that when we say Britain stands for the defence of democratic values then we are as good as our word.”The threat is also rising, from “a more aggressive Russia and a more assertive China”, Mr Hunt argued.And rapidly advancing technology could see Britain soon face a multi-dimensional assault which starts with a cyber attack and is followed by “hypersonic missiles” and “swarms of unmanned aircraft”, he warmed.The  year-old Tory MP added: “We simply do not know what the balance of power in the world will be in  years time”.It is also “not sustainable” to rely on the US’s massive defence spending while most of Europe spends so little.Mr Hunt’s aides insist it was for the MoD to map out exactly how big their raise must be.But his words will raise MPs’ hopes that the defence budget will lt from % of GDP today - the minimum NATO spending target – to %, or an extra £bn a year.Mr Hunt’s intervention risks a fresh Cabinet row by infuriating new Defence Secretary Penny Mordaunt.Neither she nor No were briefed on Mr Hunt’s speech until a few hours before he made it, it also emerged.One Cabinet source dubbed it “poor form”, as well as a tit-for-tat invitation for others to “have views on his brief”.Issuing a broad vision for post-Brexit Britain that ranged well beyond his brief, Mr Hunt also hinted tax cuts will be needed once we quit the EU – issuing a call to “put fuel in the engine of the British economy”.Mr Hunt also warned that a nuke deal row raised risks of an Iran-US war “by accident” — ahead of his talks with White House Secretary of State Mike Pompeo.His defence pledge received a warm welcome from former-forces Tory MPs.Ex-Army officer-turned Johnny Mercer said: “If we are to be the party of defence, it’s about time we proved it with the proper resourcing”.Yes, Labour: The party run by delusional peacenik Jeremy Corbyn, who wants to scrap our nuclear deterrent and cannot see “any circumstances” in which he would deploy troops.The man who said: “Wouldn’t it be wonderfulevery politician, instead of taking pride in the size of their armed forces, abolished their army ”Yet somehow, as Government cuts let our military strength wither, Labour’s defence spokeswoman Nia Grfith managed to talk tougher on nukes, troop numbers and spending than the Tories.So Jeremy Hunt’s latest salvo is a very welcome statement of intent.It is vital, the Foreign Secretary says, that we stand with America in defending the West’s democracies against the new, rising threats from an “aggressive” Russia and “assertive” China. story: It contains a brain protein that naturally helps people and animals maintain a healthy weight.When injected into mice they lost an incredible five per cent of their body fat - in just five days.Scientists are hopeful the chemical called ACBPwill have the same effect on humans.It fuels cells called astrocytes that communicate iations in fatty acids and lipids in the blood to neurons.They are vital for processing information - telling us when weve had enough to eat, say the Canadian team.Thanks to this the brain can adjust food intake and energy expenditure - and, ultimately, keep its owner slim.Targeting them in the hypothalamus - the brains hunger circuit - could be the key to controlling appetite.Professor Thierry Alquier, of Montreal University, said: With colleagues from the University of Bordeauxs NutriNeuro laboratory, we now show neurons that reduce food intake, known as proopiomelanocortin neurons or POMC neurons, are in close communication with astrocytes that produce the protein ACBP in a specic area of the brain - the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus.Essential for the control of feeding and metabolism, this area contains two types of neurons with opposing s when activated.One results in rising consumption and the second - the POMCs common to humans and animals - reduce it and increase energy expenditure.Prof Alquier said: Genetic mutations explain five to  per cent of obesity cases. Among these cases, a large proportion is related to a disruption of this neuronal pathway commonly known as the melanocortin pathway.We observed the deletion of the ACBP gene in astrocytes of the arcuate nucleus promotes obesity.In mice that were genetically modied to be obese, we observed in the laboratory that injecting them daily with ACBP led to a reduction of food intake and weight loss in the order of  per cent over five days - a mechanism that relies on the activation of POMC neurons.Uncovering the neurological causes of obesity could combat one of the biggest health problems in the world.It affects one-in-four adults in the UK and more than a third in the US - potentially leading to diabetes, heart disease, some cancers, musculoskeletal disorders and premature death.Although its driven by environmental factors - such as limitless access to sugar and fat-laden foods and increasingly sedentary lestyles - not everyone becomes overweight.It has been estimated genetics contribute up to  percent towards a persons vulnerability to piling on the pounds.Most mutations occur in the hypothalamus - a region of grey matter that monitors levels of the hormone leptin that is secreted by fat cells.Prof Alquier and colleagues said staying in shape is more brain-related than previously thought - regardless of exercise levels or food intake.He pointed out the study published in the Journal of Clinical Investigation is at the basic research stage and was carried out in laboratory experiments on mice.Prof Alquier urged caution in translating the findings to humans. title: darren lewis am hypersensitive no
story: NewsopinionDarren Lewis: Am I hypersensitive  No, just not prepared to let dodgy comedy go uncheckedI dont care what Danny Baker is or isnt, but that tweet made me feel uncomfortable and Ive had enoughShareCommentsByDarren Lewis:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsopinionDanny Baker "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFrankly, I couldn’t care less what Danny Baker is or isn’t. I’ve even less time for a police investigation into his tweet, a waste of time and resources more likely to antagonise than appease anybody. What bothers me is the ­reaction that continues to linger five days after the event. Had a fan sent that image – of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex’s baby as a chimp – to a footballer there would have been unanimity as to what it represented. The depiction of black people as simian is an old trope offensive in any context – until somebody popular does it. Then there is an element of doubt.Then we get the lectures, the famous mates hurling expletives in support and the insistence that we don’t get the joke. The radio stations that, back in December, were wringing their hands over Raheem Sterling and deploring ­football racism suddenly framing this as a two-sided debate and asking whether the critics were overreacting. I wrote back in December that we are knee-deep in a culture that emboldens xenophobia. What other conclusion can you reach when the broadcaster Janet Street-Porter argues that “we are living in an age of ­hypersensitivity”.    Hypersensitive  Growing up and in my adult le I’ve turned the other cheek to casual racism in the name of “comedy” more times than I’d care to remember. I and many, many black people I know have maintained a dignied silence, pretended not to hear certain comments, laughed them off and bitten our tongues so often we have teeth marks. My parents’ generation and millions of black and ethnic minorities in the workplace, at school and in group ­situations will have done the same.It isn’t hypersensitive to draw a line in the sand after decades of embarrassment and humiliation. Nor is it political correctness gone mad.Black people – especially young black people – are not having it any more. Like I said, I don’t know and I don’t care what Danny Baker is or isn’t. What I do know is that tweet made me uncomfortable – and black people are sick of playing down that feeling to allow other people to feel good about themselves.

story: NewsDWP apologise after woman, , stripped of pension jumped to her deathJoy Worrall committed suicide after her pension payments and winter fuel allowance were stopped for  monthsShareCommentsByOliver MilnePolitical Correspondent:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsJoy Worrall took her own le after an error saw her pensions payments stopped"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Government has apologised unreservedly after an elderly woman who was stripped of her pension - leaving her with just £ to her name - jumped to her death. -year-old Joy Worrall committed suicide after her pension payments and winter fuel allowance were stopped for  months. On Monday Work and Pensions minister Guy Opperman told MPs: The Government apologises unreservedly for the clerical error. It was a clerical error that led to Mrs Worrallaposs pension payment being stopped. Mrs Worall plunged off a quarry one mile from her home in the Welsh village of Rhes-y-Cae, Flintshire, in November last year. But there is an internal process review and I undertake to write to the honourable gentleman with what we do know in the short term, and more detail when the urgent processes review has taken place.    The pensioner had received an inheritance in , and told the DWP about it. But in , her pension situation was re-assessed and instead of only freezing the pension credits Mrs Worrall received, the DWP froze her ordinary state pension. She told the Mirror she brought a photograph of herself, rather than a photo ID, after she misunderstood the instructions.   Cat Smith, Labour ’s Shadow Minister for Voter Engagement, said: As we feared, legitimate and honest voters have been denied their right to vote because of these undemocratic and unpopular pilot schemes.Time and time again Labour has warned that Voter ID will make it harder for people to vote but the Conservatives have pushed on with their blatant attempt to rig the result of future elections by voter suppression. After another round of shambolic pilot schemes, itaposs clear that Voter ID has no place in our democracy and should be abandoned immediately. It came as a cross-party letter urged ministers to abandon the plan, saying it would disproportionately affect vulnerable people and communities and was an attempt at voter suppression.”   The letter, from Labour, the Liberal Democrats , SNP , Plaid Cymru and the Green Party read: “The Windrush scandal has demonstrated very clearly that it can be more dficult for some communities to provide official documentation than others.“As representatives of major opposition parties, we believe that what is really going on here is a blatant attempt by the Conservatives to rig the result of future elections by making it harder for people to vote – it’s voter suppression. “At a time when millions of people are missing from the electoral register, we won’t allow this government to close down our democracy. “In light of the overwhelming evidence base, we are of the collective view that these dangerous voter ID trials must be scrapped as a matter of urgency.”

title: jeremy hunt demands more cash
story: NewsJeremy Hunt demands more cash for military as Tory leadership battle escalatesThe Foreign Secretary used a major policy speech to the Lord Mayor’s Banquet at London’s Mansion House to back calls for extra cash for the militaryShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsHunt is seen as a front runner to replace Theresa May at No "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Jeremy Hunt has demanded a hike in defence spending as he launched the latest salvo in his thinly-veiled bid to succeed Theresa May .The Foreign Secretary used a major policy speech to the Lord Mayor’s Banquet at London’s Mansion House to back calls for extra cash for the military - a key plea from high-profile Conservative backbenchers. Britain is one of a handful of NATO nations to meet the alliance benchmark of pumping % of GDP into its Armed Forces – and a host of prominent Tory backbenchers want a lt. Many see it as a rallying point for hawkish right-wingers, and a potential party leadership candidate would boost their hopes by pressing for a rise.    Warning of the mounting threats from “more aggressive Russia and a more assertive China”, Mr Hunt said: “I believe it is time for the next Strategic Defence and Security Review to ask whether, over the coming decade, we should decisively increase the proportion of GDP we devote to defence. “Any additional funds would of course need to be for new capabilities and not simply plugging gaps in existing plans – and our aim, as ever, is to deter and avoid the horror of war in the knowledge that strength is the surest guarantee of peace. “The outcome of such investment should demonstrate beyond doubt that when we say Britain stands for the defence of democratic values, when we promise never to leave our great ally, the United States, to perform this task alone then we are as good as our word and in doing so we encourage other democracies who share our values to follow suit.” Just seven of  NATO countries meet the % guideline, despite mounting demands from Donald Trump for European states to stump up more cash. The US injected .% of GDP into defence last year, with the UK hitting .%.    But the Commons Defence Committee, retired top brass and a host of senior Tories have ramped up calls for extra money. Being seen as sympathetic to those pleas will boost Mr Hunt’s chances of claiming the Conservative crown when Mrs May finally quits No. Mr Hunt, who meets NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg on Tuesday, has yet to confirm he will run to replace the Prime Minister. Declared hopefuls so far include International Development Secretary Rory Stewart, Chief Secretary to the Treasury Liz Truss, Commons Leader Andrea Leadsom and former Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey. Others expected to throw their hats into the ring include former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson and ex-Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab.

story: NewsSending kids to boxing and karate will help fight kne crime MPs claimThe Commons Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Committee has said the Government has overlooked the importance of exercise and culture in dealing with the problemShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsPhysical activity could help tackle Britains kne epidemic "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSending kids to boxing and martial arts’ classes could help fight kne crime and gang violence, MPs claim. The Commons Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Committee accuses the Government of overlooking sporting and cultural activities in favour of arresting and jailing youngsters over Britain’s blade culture. Walking, football and choral singing could also be key to solving social problems in health, education and urban regeneration, it claims. The report recommends that sport and culture are “better integrated within the work and policy objectives” of Whitehall departments to make them a “mainstream” way of delivering policy. Committee chairman Damian Collins said: “We cannot break the debilitating cycle of gang violence and kne crime just by arresting those who commit offences.    “Government statistics clearly show that custodial sentences in and of themselves do not necessarily rehabilitate young offenders. “In schools we have seen that sport and culture can improve educational attainment as well as the well-being of the students. “Social activities like group singing and walking football can improve the mental and physical health of those who take part. “More needs to be done to co-ordinate and invest in community initiatives, share evidence of success and encourage others to emulate examples of best practice.” The report highlights boxing and martial arts programmes as particularly useful in reaching young people, and calls for a Government review of their effectiveness in prisons. title: dr miriam stoppard social media
story: NewsopinionDr Miriam Stoppard: Social media is no help to those who self-harmMore children that ever are being hospitalised due to self-harm. In , , youngsters aged between nine and  were taken to hospital with self-harm injuries. The figure last year was ,.Last year,  cases involved ­children aged between nine and , up from  in . Girls were five times as likely to be admitted as boys. The fear is that self-harm images online may be normalising the ­behaviour. After her death in , -year-old Molly Russell’s family found she had been shown material online linked to anxiety, depression, self-harm and suicide.In the week after her father, Ian Russell, spoke out, a further  families came forward to say they thought social media had played a role in their children’s suicides.Dr Hayley van Zwanenberg, a child and ­adolescent psychiatrist at the Priory’s Wellbeing Centre in Oxford, said: “Self-harm is becoming endemic among schoolchildren.    “We’re seeing increasing numbers at the Priory who feel inadequate ­physically and socially they’re bombarded with digitally enhanced images of celebrities, and friends’ ­bragging selfies.If a young person doesn’t have perfect skin, or enough ‘likes’, they can quickly feel negative about themselves, worthless and ­overwrought.“When I ask a child where he or she has learnt ways to self-harm, they iniably cite the internet or a friend who has learned from the internet.” Dr Louise Theodosiou, of the Royal College of Psychiatrists, said that there was “the potential for websites to be normalising self-harm”. A Department of Health and Social Care spokesman said: “The ­Government is committed to improving the mental health and ­wellbeing of young people and addressing issues such as self-harm, and we are transforming their mental health services – backed by £.billion last year alone.“We are ensuring , more ­children will have access to specialist mental health care by  .” But the Royal College of Physicians fears young people may be struggling to get help with mental health issues. title: familys horror man treated worse
story: NewsFamilys horror as man treated worse than animal in three-week care home stayThe family of Hugh Caldwell, , paid £, for his short respite stay at the care home and claim his room was filthy and mouldyShareCommentsByAmanda Keenan:,  MAY NewsHughs sisters Christine Livingston and Maisie Caldwell have complained about the levels of care at the home "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man was left covered in agonising blisters and puss-filled sores after a short stint at a private care home while his family attended a wedding abroad, it has been claimed.Spina bida sufferer Hugh Caldwell was treated worse than an animal and contracted sepsis while in Castle View in Dumbarton, Scotland.The -year-old would normally be looked after by his sisters, Maisie and Christine. title: fed up waste 20 tips
story: NewsFed up of waste   tips to help you cut down on how much food you throw awayWe all need to do our bit when it comes to waste - so weve got  little things you can do every week to make a dferenceShareByNada Farhoud:,  MAY News "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSound familiar  Head to the supermarket with a shopping list of fresh food, only to find the bin bulging with the rotting remains of our best intentions  The UK wastes . million tons of food a year – with the majority of it down to us at home. And the hospitality and food service industry throws out the equivalent of . billion meals a year – one in six dished up. But ­now Britain’s biggest supermarkets, suppliers and manufacturers and hospitality businesses have pledged to halve food waste by . Plans include serving smaller portions of chips and offering diners “doggy bags”.  The Government’s waste ­reduction advisory body, Waste and Resources Action Programme, has created an action plan to slash the £billion worth of food wasted by restaurants, cafes, hotels and canteens every year – % of which could have been eaten. Its s Of Grub campaign, backed by Environment Secretary Michael Gove, will encourage doggy bags, arguing they could help slash % of waste related to customer leftovers. A Wrap spokesman said: “Offering the option of smaller portion sizes for commonly wasted foods before they are cooked might help reduce waste.” And  firms including Nestle, Tesco and Sainsbury’s signed up to halve waste by  at a Step Up To The Plate event yesterday. But here’s what can we do as ­iniduals to help cut food waste before that date... . Plan the week’s meals in advance so you know the ingredients you’ll need – this will help save a few quid. . Stick to your shopping list – don’t be tempted by buy-one-get-one-free deals for things you don’t need and won’t use.    . Don’t go food shopping when you’re hungry – it’s too tempting to load up on too many treats. . Buy items that can be used in dferent dishes, like minced beef, veg and cans of tomatoes. . Look for food with the longest use-by dates and fresh foods that can be frozen. . Shop local. You will be less tempted to bulk buy while helping your community. . Wrap.org.uk has a handy portion size planner, such as g of rice per person and other tips to help you cut back on waste. . We often shop in a hurry. Don’t panic-buy,possible. . Providing eggs are cooked thoroughly, they can be eaten a day or two after best-before dates. . For foods with a best-before date, use your senses to checkthey are good to eat. But stick to use-by dates – or freeze them. . Sort out the fridge. Wrap up cheese, sliced meats or sausages to stop them drying out. Bring the oldest foods to the front so they don’t get forgotten. . Milk not used up before its use-by date accounts for half of what is thrown away. Freeze at any time until this date, in ice cube traysspace is tight.    . Store produce in the right place to keep it fresh for longer. Don’t put potatoes in the fridge and invest in a bread bin. . Don’t serve huge portions and use smaller plates. . Is there any food in your cupboards you could donate to foodbanks before you chuck it  . Remember the days when people pickled and canned their own food  Making jam or chutney could save fruit and veg before it rots. . Food waste has gone digital. Check out apps for more advice. . Recycle meals with ideas at lovefood hatewaste recipes . If you have a garden or allotment, you can compost those leftovers. . Keep accountable by keeping track of what you dump.

story: NewsIve spent  years hunting for where killer hid my dead sons bodyEXCLUSIVE: Sheila Dolton is backing the Mirrors Helens Law campaign, which has already received , signaturesShareCommentsByLouie SmithFiona Duffy:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsSheila Dolton "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA grieving mum who has been searching for her son’s body for  years is supporting calls for Helen’s Law. Sheila Dolton, , is backing the bid to deny parole to killers who refuse to disclose where their victims’ bodies are. The campaign, which was launched in the Mirror, has , signatures of support. Sheila spends her weekends in remote countryside in the hope of finding son Jonathan’s remains so he can finally be laid to rest. She said: “No other family should be put through this torment. We desperately need Helen’s Law put in place... The grieving process involves falling apart and putt­ing yourself back together – learning to move on without that person. Without our son’s body to bury, we can’t do that.”    Jonathan was  when he was killed in  by business partner Stewart Martin, who fled to Australia but was extradited, convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to seven-and-a-half years. Sheila repeatedly sent letters begging the killer to reveal the location of Jonathan’s body, but to no avail. Martin was released on licence in  after serving just over four years. He died of a heart attack  months later aged , taking his secrets to the grave.    He’d had a few hours to hide the body. Sheila’s search has slowly fanned out from Jonathan’s home in Milton Keynes, Bucks, where blood was found in his car. Retired civil servant Sheila, of Oxford, said: “I go deep into wooded areas... At times it’s terrying. “Once, I got lost as night fell. I stumbled about in the dark in sheer panic. “I sat down and sobbed. Finally, I found a path. I always pack a survival blanket and compass now.” The gran, married to Alan, , added: “We feel it’s our duty as Jonathan’s parents to find him.” Marie McCourt, , of Billinge, Merseyside, is behind the Helen’s Law campaign launched in  and named after her murdered daughter Helen. title: lottery winner called everyone knew
story: NewsLottery winner called everyone he knew over £, scoop before gutting blowDean Smethurst, , cracked open the bubbly and started making plans for the future after a Tesco checkout worker told him he had won a prize in Saturdays drawShareCommentsByDaniel Sheridan:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsDean said his mum made him some comfort food but it wasnt much comfort "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who believed he had scooped £, on the National Lottery rang up everyone he knew before realising he had actually won just £ of prizes. Dean Smethurst, , had his national lotto card checked in Tesco on May  and was told by the woman on the checkout he had won on the Saturday game. The supermarket worker told Dean the machine said she could not pay out his winnings and he would have to instead contact Camelot. This prompted Dean to check the terms and conditions of the Camelot website - where he realised this message was usually given for wins of at least £k which could not be paid out in a retail shop. In a state of shock, Dean - a supermarket manager who has played the lottery for six years - dashed home before telling all of his friends and family the news. He began to work out what he could spend the money on and aposcracked open the bubblyapos - without thinking to check his numbers against the draw.    However, when the lottery phone lines opened again the next morning, Dean was given the devastating news that his luck was out. His win actually turned out to be three lucky dips on a future game - worth just £ each. He said: I didn’t sleep because I was so excited. My house is like a building site at the moment so that was the first thing that I decided to spend my winnings on. Then I decided to treat the family to a luxury holiday to Barbados. I spoke to the checkout girl and gave her the serial number of the ticket. She inputted it and said: ‘Well done, you’ve won...three lucky dips’. I asked hershe was sure, and then I asked to speak to a manager. I am absolutely gutted. I thought, ‘this is it, it’s for real, my numbers have come up’. I never thought to check my numbers, I didnapost think a company as large as Camelot could have got it wrong, I didnapost understand.    His roller-coaster ride to riches and back began on Wednesday evening when he had his lotto card checked at the Farnworth Tesco store, Lancs., - a store where he worked earlier in his career. Dean said: “I’d gone in to do a bit of shopping and I thought I’d check to see how I’d gone on in the previous Saturday’s draw. “All the other staff applauded me. “The receipt said I’d won a prize, that the store would not be able to pay it out and that I should contact Camelot immediately.” Unfortunately, the phone lines were closed for the night so Dean went online and learned that he had potentially won at least £,. He then set about about sharing the good news with his nearest and dearest. When the Camelot phone lines reopened at am on Thursday an excited Dean, who is currently in the process of renovating his £, home, made the phone call he thought would change his le for ever. It emerged that because the Wednesday lottery draw was in progress while Dean had his Saturday ticket checked, the checkout girl got that particular receipt message.  Dean said: When I had purchased the ticket I had bought one for both the Saturday and Wednesday draw. As the Wednesday draw was in the process of taking place, it looks like this was an automated message instead which would have been given for any win. I was absolutely gutted. It is back to the drawing board now. A spokesman for Camelot said: “In this instance, the player attempted to claim a prize during a aposdraw breakapos, when National Lottery sales are suspended while a draw takes place. The prize couldn’t be paid out at that time - because the ticket was still entered into a aposliveapos draw - so a validation slip was printed instead. To clary, this generic slip is used for a number of scenarios - itaposs not exclusively used for high-tier prizes. Poor Dean was relieved he had the day off on Thursday so he didnapost have to face his colleagues . He said: I just watched television and my mum made me some comfort food, which wasnapost much comfort.

title: miss england 2018 winner reveals
story: NewsMiss England  winner reveals devastating health battle she faces every dayAlisha Cowie had to ask the Miss England judges to repeat one of the questions - but it didnt stop the ambitious student from taking the titleShareCommentsByPeter Robertson:,  MAY NewsAlisha Cowie is fulfilling her Miss England duties "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIn September , as the finalists of the Miss England pageant waited to hear which of them was the winner, none was listening more intently than the then Miss Newcastle, Alisha Cowie. That’s because Geordie student Alisha, now , who was duly announced as Miss England, had been suffering hearing loss for four years. “It was very scary,” she recalls. “I was OK with one-on-one ­conversations indoors, but I ­struggled to keep upI was talking to two or more people. When I was in a crowded place, everything was just noise to me and I could never make voices and conversations out.“I’d go completely deaf outside in windy weather and wouldn’t go to a rock concert or anything really loud. It was annoying and embarrassing because I’d have to ask people to repeat themselves.“When I was asked a question by the Miss England judges, I had to ask for that to be repeated.”    Alisha, who was born in ­Gateshead and raised in Newcastle, recalls, “In , I noticed that my hearing was going in one ear. The problem came and went. I was only  and assumed it was temporary. But when I hit  it became worse so I visited my GP. He checked my ear health and said it was fine. “The problem got worse but I was told repeatedly there was nothing wrong.” Then, last August, just before her th birthday, Alisha visited Boots for a hearing test. She wasn’t prepared for the news that she had premature hearing loss in both of her ears. “I knew I had an issue with my right ear, which is why I had gone for help, but apparently my right ear was only slightly worse than my left, which I hadn’t realised. The audiologist performed the test twice because he couldn’t believe that an -year-old could have such bad hearing loss.” Alisha was devastated. “I was told my hearing could stay that way forever, or it could deteriorate further. I was shocked. I thought I was too young for something like this to happen.” At the time, Alisha was studying Crime Scene Investigation And Forensic Science at Teesside University, hoping to become a detective.    She had no idea how the diagnosis would affect her future. The audiologist referred her on to an ear specialist for further investigations, so she simply had to wait. Her confidence was knocked, and Alisha almost didn’t compete in the Miss England competition the following month for fear her dficulties would hold her back, but finally resolved to go for it. “I decided that I couldn’t let it get me down,” she explains. “I began to learn sign language and to lip read, sothe worst was to happen I’d have options and it would not be the end of the world. I’ll be honest, I’m still not great at signing.” Since taking the title, Alisha has been busy fulfilling official duties as Miss England, all the while still waiting for her appointment with the specialist. So when, during an interview on BBC Breakfast in April this year, Alisha had to ask co-hosts Louise Minchin and Dan Walker to repeat their questions, her hearing ­problems were spotted by an employee of private healthcare company Hidden Hearing, who invited her into the company’s Newcastle branch for further tests. “They told me the problem could be ­hereditary, that I could have been born with damage to the tiny bones in my ears, or perhaps I’d hit my head as a child which could cause damage to the nerves or bones. “If my problem is to do with the bones rather than nerves it’s unlikely to get worse. An operation could fix them but that comes with the risk of nerve damage. I felt that, for me, the best option was hearing aids.” Hidden Hearing fitted Alisha with their Oticon Opn S hearing aids, which – unlike traditional aids which restrict focus to one sound at a time – give your brain access to more sounds around you. “I wear them all the time, except when I go to sleep,” says Alisha. “They’re making a massive ­dference. Now I can even hear what somebody behind me is saying. They’re also discreet, but I wouldn’t be embarrassedpeople know I wear them. Lots of people lose their hearing.” “I will probably have to wear hearing aids for the rest of my le, but I’m fine about that,” she adds. “They’re already making my le so much better.”For further information, visit hiddenhearing

Footage went viral after being circulated on social media by Britainaposs Got Talent judge Amanda Holden, who asked the public to call  or u know these scumbags. Now the politan Police has released CCTV of a police chase of a moped, which can be seen swerving around the streets. The chase then continues on foot before they are finally caught. Among the bold crimes committed by the gang between July  and June  was the theft of BBC camera equipment filming the Oxford versus Cambridge boat race. Judge Georgina Kent told the -strong gang, who were crowded into the dock at Kingston Crown Court: Many offences were committed using motorbikes or mopeds, often stolen with  number plates. Many offences offences were committed at night. She added: The motorbike helmets and clothing, often all in black, were an effective disguise and created an intimidating appearance. The motorbikes provided a quick getaway. Many of these offences were committed in public view because you were confident you could get away with it.    In what the judge described as an exceptionally serious and shocking attempted robbery which had a degree of planning, four gang members were caught on CCTV targeting a woman with a young child in broad daylight in Richmond. Pheobe Ruele was walking hand-in-hand with her son whom she had just picked up from nursery when two motorcycles road past, pulled into the road and waited for her on June  last year. The court heard that John McFadyen, , grabbed her arm hard enough to leave finger-mark bruises and told her: Give me your rings. Iaposm going to hurt your child and take him away. Footage shows the terried woman dragging her child into the road before builders chase the gang away, brandishing scaffolding poles.  The judge noted that fortunately there were no cars in the vicinity at that moment but added that Ms Ruele is now afraid for her childrenaposs safety when she takes them to and from school. The judge said she had no doubt this offence would have struck fear into any parent who heard about it. The judge added: A mother and her three-year-old son are extremely vulnerable. The threats that were made were calculated to exploit that vulnerability. To threaten a mother with violence towards a very young child and threaten to take the child away is a most effective and distressing threat. The footage went viral after being circulated on social media by Britainaposs Got Talent judge Amanda Holden, who asked the public to call  or u know these scumbags.  Taking the gang off the streets has helped cut moped-enabled crime in the capital by % in the space of a year, according to the politan Police. The defendants, who are aged between  and , also used their mopeds to block traffic before taking an angle grinder to cameras rigged up to capture the boat race on March  last year. Although their first attempt on Putney Bridge was interrupted by off-duty police officer Steven Wagstaff, a highly-specialised BBC camera worth an estimated £, was stolen by Barnes Bridge just an hour later. Of the first incident, the judge said: One of the riders rode at Mr Wagstaff, kicking out with his foot. Another threatened to stab him and one of the pillionthreatened to stab him with the angle grinder. The gang escaped empty-handed.  The gang, who were all linked to ringleader Terry Marsh, , were sentenced for offences including conspiracy to rob, conspiracy to burgle,conspiracy to steal, criminal damage and handling stolen goods. They had arranged for an associate to wait by the roadside with a can of fuel to try to escape. The three, who had tried to film the escapade, were arrested when they crashed by South Ealing Cemetery.    The gang first came to police attention on December   when they carried out a ram-raid on high-end outdoor clothing company Altimus Ltd in High Street Kensington using a stolen Range Rover and several mopeds. They made off with thousands of poundsapos worth of Canada Goose and Nicole Benisti jackets which can retail at up to £,. Within a month, the gang had ed to the same store to carry out a second raid, violently assaulting the security guard hired to protect the premises and throwing him out into the street. The two raids cost the business £, in lost goods, and a total of £, including damage. The judge said the security guard, who was just doing his job, suffered head injuries, bruises to his body and a foot injury. She added: Since then he felt unprotected when he goes to work and he is afraid that something like this could happen again.  Other brazen attacks included spraying a police car with fire foam extinguishers as officers waited for a stolen moped to be collected, and making off with the bike. They also targeted two unmarked police cars, stealing an officeraposs bag from one and smashing another up with a hammer in a bid to do as much damage as possible. Mitchell Leaver,  of Battersea, was given a -month suspended sentence and and a three-month curfew after admitting conspiracy to burgle. story: NewsMum, , went out for lunch with baby daughter hours before jumping off A bridgeThe family of Stephanie Housley saw no warning signs that the mum-of-one was planning to take her own le, an inquest heardShareCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter:,  MAY NewsBrother and sister Simon and Stephanie Housley "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum-of-one went out for lunch with her daughter hours before she jumped from a bridge and took her own le.Stephanie Housley was suffering from postnatal depression after the birth of her daughter, an inquest heard. An inquest heard Stephanie had given birth to her first daughter in March  and been diagnosed with postnatal depression three months later as her daughter suffered with colic. But her family saw no warning signs that she was planning to take her own le.    She had been out for lunch with a relative and her daughter at the Weathervane pub, in Meir Park, on the day of her death. In a statement read out at yesterdayaposs inquest, Stephanieaposs partner James Walton said: Iaposve been in a relationship with Steph for  months. We found out we were having a baby together, moved in together, and were so happy. Following the birth of our daughter, Steph suffered with postnatal depression. Steph was admitted to a parent and baby unit to receive some support. It started to become easier and Steph went back to work as a carer at UK Care Management. She loved caring for people, although she did not enjoy the long hours. It restricted time with her daughter as she did -hour shts two days a week. This was due to change to three days, that was the only thing playing on Stephaposs mind, she just wanted to be a mum. The inquest heard Stephanie had attempted to kill herself twice before and her dad committed suicide when she was a child. They then walked to Tesco, at Meir Park, before the relative took Stephanieaposs daughter home. A dog-walker saw Stephanie sitting cross-legged on the bridge at .pm on March . She said: She turned to me and smiled. She looked very well presented and did not look upset. So I carried on walking my dog. I looked back but carried on walking down and I called  and then  to raise concerns. But the inquest heard Stephanie fell to her death before the police could arrive. story: NewsMum-of-three, , loses three stone by ditching bread and butterDawne Dickey, from Belfast, dropped an incredible four dress sizes after changing her dietShareCommentsBySarah Scott:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsMum Dawne has lost three stone after ditching one thing from her diet "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum-of-three has lost three stone by ditching her biggest vice - bread and butter. Dawne Dickey, , looks unrecognisable after dropping the household staple from her diet. At her heaviest Dawne weighed  stone and decided to take action when her weight started to affect her health.The weight started to fall off after she joined the Lisburn WST Community group and she dropped an incredible four dress sizes, reports Belfast Live.She now wears size  clothes instead of size - and feels a lot more confident in herself.    Dawne said the secret to her success was a lestyle change as well as cutting out her beloved bread and real butter. Sixteen or seventeen years ago I lost a lot of weight but I put it all on again with health complications, said Dawne. Then I saw the ad for WST starting a group in Lisburn so I thought I would join, that was three years ago in August and I was just over  stone when I joined.It was affecting my health, I have arthritis in my knees and that was my big issue, I also have rheumatoid arthritis in my hands and feet which made moving dficult.   Dawne says the community group doesnapost use the word aposdietapos and focuses on changing attitudes towards food. She cut out all processed foods and focused on cooking healthy, home-made dishes instead. Cutting out bread and cereal was a big thing for me, she said. Bread and real butter would be my downfall. I do have treat days andI fancy some I will but that is the dference, you are not on a diet. You donapost get downyou have a bad day, you just start again the next day. When you go to class, you donapost have to stand in front of everyone and tell them what happenedyou gained that week, it is up to youyou want to share.  Dawne says she now loves shopping for clothes and is more confident after losing weight. It is a lestyle change and this is for le, she said. I donapost fixate on being on a diet as I would end up eating more, this takes the pressure off yourself and you are not as hard on yourself. If you have a bad day forget about it and start new the next day, do not wait for Monday, Monday never comes. She has also become fitter and earlier this month, Dawne took on a  mile walk from Ballynahinch to Kilkeel and back to raise money for Air Ambulance NI after they helped her daughter Robyn following a serious crash in July last year.
